curriculumTitle: Architectural Engineering & Design: From Foundations to Future Skylines
overview: A comprehensive 20-lesson STEM curriculum exploring the intersection of art, engineering, and mathematics through architecture. Designed specifically for DOE TRIO programs (UB/UBMS) in Texas, this course scaffolds students from historical foundations to structural physics, transitioning into modern CAD technology and sustainable design. The curriculum emphasizes college readiness in STEM fields, utilizing Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) and fulfilling federal grant objectives regarding rigorous curriculum and exposure to postsecondary programs.
prerequisites: Completion of Algebra I (or concurrent enrollment); Basic computer literacy.

fieldTrips.name: University of Texas at Arlington - CAPPA Tour
fieldTrips.description: A guided tour of the College of Architecture, Planning, and Public Affairs (CAPPA) at UTA, including the Digital Fabrication Lab.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Fulfills HEA requirement for exposure to postsecondary education. Students visualize the college pathway for Architecture and Architectural Engineering majors.

fieldTrips.name: Perot Museum of Nature and Science - Engineering Hall
fieldTrips.description: Interactive exploration of the Texas Instruments Engineering and Innovation Hall, focusing on structural dynamics and materials.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Reinforces Activity 4 (Forces) and Activity 10 (Earthquakes) through hands-on exhibits on static loads and seismic engineering.

fieldTrips.name: Kimbell Art Museum (Louis Kahn Building)
fieldTrips.description: Architectural tour focusing on the cycloid barrel vaults and natural light diffusion systems designed by Louis Kahn.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Direct application of Activity 14 (Solar Studies) and Activity 3 (Geometry/Golden Ratio), analyzing natural light and concrete construction.

activities.title: 1. Form Follows Function: Introduction to Architecture
activities.description: Students define architecture and analyze everyday buildings to understand the relationship between aesthetic form and practical function.
learningObjectives: Define architecture and distinguish it from construction.
Analyze a structure based on the principle of 'Form Follows Function'.
Identify key architectural styles in their local community.
teks: 130.42(c)(1)(A) (Principles of Architecture): Demonstrate knowledge of the history of architecture.
130.42(c)(4)(A): Apply the concepts of form and function.

detailed: Present slides showing contrasting buildings (e.g., a Gothic cathedral vs. a modern office).
Lead a discussion on why buildings look the way they do, introducing the phrase 'Form Follows Function' (Louis Sullivan).
Introduce the sketchbooks as their 'Architectural Journal' for the course, emphasizing that architects think through drawing.

brief: Redesign it for a new function.
detailed: Sketch one object in the room (e.g., a chair).
Redesign that object to change its function (e.g., a chair that becomes a table).
Write a reflection on how the shape changed when the function changed.

trioCompliance.justification: Provides necessary exposure to STEM careers (Architecture) and supplies essential for the curriculum execution.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.453 (Supplies: Sketchbooks are necessary for the performance of the award)

activities.title: 2. Ancient Engineering: The Geometry of Pyramids
activities.description: Exploration of the structural stability of the pyramid shape and the mathematics behind calculating volume and surface area.
learningObjectives: Calculate the slope, volume, and surface area of a pyramid.
Understand why the pyramid shape was structurally necessary for ancient civilizations.
teks: 111.43(c)(10)(B) (Geometry): Determine the area of composite figures.

detailed: Review the geometric formulas for pyramids (Volume = 1/3 Base x Height).
Discuss the distribution of weight in a wide-base structure versus a vertical column.
Challenge students to build the tallest paper pyramid that can hold a 1lb sandbag.
Calculate the required base size for a 10-inch tall pyramid using provided formulas.
Cut and assemble the pyramid using cardstock and tape.
Test stability by carefully placing the sandbag weight on top.

trioCompliance.justification: Direct instruction in Geometry (Math) utilizing hands-on engineering application.

activities.title: 3. The Golden Ratio in Classical Architecture
activities.description: Students investigate the Parthenon and Greek orders to understand how the Golden Ratio (Phi) influences aesthetic proportions.
learningObjectives: Define the Golden Ratio (1:1.618).
Apply algebraic ratios to architectural measurement.
Identify Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian columns.
teks: 111.39(c)(1)(A) (Algebra I): Apply mathematics to problems arising in everyday life.
130.46(c)(6)(B): Apply the principles of scale and proportion.

detailed: Teach the mathematical derivation of Phi (1.618...).
Show examples of the Golden Rectangle overlay on the Parthenon.
Guide students in measuring printed images to verify if the proportions fit the ratio.
Measure the width and height of various architectural features (columns, entablature).
Calculate the ratio (Width / Height) to see if it approximates 1.618.
Sketch a building facade using the Golden Ratio as a guide.

trioCompliance.justification: Math instruction focused on Algebra and Geometry concepts applied to design.

activities.title: 4. The Roman Arch: Keystone Physics
activities.description: A physics-focused lesson on how arches redirect vertical force into horizontal thrust, allowing for open spaces.
learningObjectives: Explain compression forces in an arch.
Identify the role of the keystone.
Construct a self-supporting arch.
teks: 112.39(c)(4)(D) (Physics): Analyze the free-body diagram for a system of forces.
130.46(c)(9)(A): Describe the forces acting on a structure.

materialsList.item: High-density Foam blocks or Wooden Voussoirs

detailed: Demonstrate how a beam fails under load (bending) versus an arch (compression).
Draw force vectors on the board showing load transfer down the arch legs.
Supervise the construction of a voussoir arch using the kits.
Work in teams to stack blocks into an arch form over a temporary support.
Insert the keystone at the top center.
Remove the support (centering) and see if the arch stands.
Apply gentle downward pressure to test strength.

trioCompliance.justification: Physics instruction regarding force vectors and static equilibrium.

activities.title: 5. Gothic Engineering: Flying Buttresses
activities.description: Understanding how external supports allow for taller walls and larger windows (stained glass) by counteracting lateral thrust.
learningObjectives: Understand the concept of lateral thrust.
Design a support system to prevent wall collapse.
Relate structural innovation to aesthetic changes (light).

materialsList.item: Hot Glue Guns and Glue Sticks

detailed: Explain the limitations of the Roman Arch (thick walls needed to contain thrust).
Introduce the Pointed Arch and Flying Buttress concepts.
Challenge students to build two walls that support a heavy roof without collapsing outward.
Build two parallel cardboard walls.
Place a heavy roof on top and observe the walls bowing out.
Design and attach cardboard buttresses to support the walls from the outside.
Retest the load to demonstrate stability.

trioCompliance.justification: Hands-on physics lab exploring vector forces and structural stability.

activities.title: 6. Tension vs. Compression: Bridge Building I
activities.description: Introduction to the two primary forces in engineering through a truss analysis.
learningObjectives: Differentiate between tension and compression.
Identify truss members under tension vs compression.
Build a simple truss.
teks: 130.362(c)(6)(A) (Engineering Design): Identify the principles of engineering.

detailed: Draw a truss bridge on the board.
Use colored markers to indicate which beams are being squeezed (compression-Red) and which are pulled (tension-Blue).
Explain why triangles are rigid geometric shapes compared to squares.
Construct a single 2D truss unit (triangle based) using sticks.
Wait for glue to dry (or use clips to hold).
Predict where the truss would break under load based on the lesson.

trioCompliance.justification: Core STEM activity focusing on Engineering principles and Physics.

activities.title: 7. Blueprint Basics: Scale and Measurement
activities.description: Students learn to read and use an architect's scale ruler to interpret floor plans.
learningObjectives: Read an architectural scale ruler (1/4" = 1').
Convert real-world measurements to scale measurements.
Draw a simple room to scale.
teks: 130.46(c)(3)(A) (Architectural Design I): Use architectural measuring tools.

detailed: Demonstrate the different sides of the scale ruler (specifically the 1/4 inch scale).
Explain why scale is necessary (buildings don't fit on paper).
Provide a worksheet with lines to measure and convert.
Measure the classroom perimeter using a standard tape measure.
Convert the measurement using 1/4 inch scale (1 real foot = 1/4 paper inch).
Draw the classroom perimeter on graph paper using the scale ruler.

trioCompliance.justification: Applied mathematics and vocational skill building (using technical tools).

activities.title: 8. Orthographic Projection: Elevations
activities.description: Learning to visualize 3D objects in 2D space by drawing front, side, and top views.
learningObjectives: Understand the concept of orthographic projection.
Draw the elevations of a simple object (e.g., a lego house).
Align views correctly on drafting paper.

detailed: Explain the 'Glass Box' theory of projection (unfolding the sides of a box).
Show examples of blueprints (Plan, Section, Elevation).
Assign each student a unique Lego structure to document.

brief: Draw Front and Side views aligned.
detailed: Observe the Lego structure from a strictly 90-degree angle.
Draw the Top View.
Draw the Front View directly below the top view (projecting lines down).
Draw the Right Side View to the right of the front view (projecting lines across).

trioCompliance.justification: Development of spatial reasoning skills required for Engineering and Math.

activities.title: 9. Material Science: Concrete Lab
activities.description: Mixing and testing different ratios of sand, cement, and aggregate to understand material strength.
learningObjectives: Understand the chemical reaction of hydration.
Compare concrete mixes with different aggregate ratios.
Mold concrete into test shapes.

detailed: Review safety protocols (cement is caustic and can burn skin).
Explain the chemistry of curing (it's not 'drying', it is an exothermic chemical reaction called hydration).
Assign different mix ratios to different groups (e.g., 1:1 vs 1:3).
Mix cement, sand, and water according to assigned ratio.
Pour into cup molds and tap vigorously to remove air bubbles.
Label cups with the ratio used and set aside to cure for 24-48 hours.

trioCompliance.justification: Chemistry and Materials Science laboratory instruction.

activities.title: 10. Earthquake Engineering: Shake Tables
activities.description: Designing structures that can withstand lateral seismic loads using a simple shake table.
learningObjectives: Understand resonance and damping.
Build a tower with cross-bracing.
Test failure points under dynamic load.

detailed: Discuss how earthquakes affect buildings (shear force/lateral movement).
Show videos of tuned mass dampers in skyscrapers.
Create a simple shake table (cardboard platform rolling on marbles with rubber bands for tension).
Build a tower at least 12 inches tall using straws.
Secure it to the shake table base.
Simulate an earthquake and observe deformation.
Add cross-bracing to improve performance and retest.

trioCompliance.justification: Integration of Earth Science (Geophysics) and Structural Engineering.

activities.title: 11. Digital Design: Intro to CAD (Tinkercad)
activities.description: Introduction to Computer-Aided Design (CAD) using free browser-based software to create digital 3D models.
learningObjectives: Navigate 3D space on a computer screen.
Place and resize primitive shapes.
Group objects to create complex forms.

detailed: Demonstrate the workplane, camera controls, and basic shapes in Tinkercad.
Explain additive vs subtractive modeling (Holes vs Solids).
Assign a simple task: Build a digital house with a roof and door.
Log in to Tinkercad (Classroom account).
Complete the 'Starters' tutorial to learn navigation.
Build a simple house with a roof, door hole, and window holes.

trioCompliance.justification: Modern technical skills required for postsecondary STEM education.

activities.title: 12. 3D Modeling: Interior Walls
activities.description: Advanced CAD usage to design interior layouts with specific dimensions and partitions.
learningObjectives: Design to specific dimensions in CAD.
Create interior partitions.
Understand wall thickness.

detailed: Discuss standard wall thickness (4.5 to 6 inches for residential).
Show how to use the 'ruler' tool in CAD for precision placement.
Challenge students to create a 2-bedroom layout within a set footprint.
Create a floor slab of 30x40 feet.
Extrude exterior walls (ensuring thickness).
Add interior walls to create rooms, ensuring walls are accurate thickness.

trioCompliance.justification: Technical skill building for Architecture/Engineering fields.

activities.title: 13. Site Analysis: Topography
activities.description: Understanding contour lines and how to design buildings that respect the landscape using physical models.
learningObjectives: Read a topographical map.
Create a physical model of a landscape using layers (chipboard).
Determine the best location for a building on a slope.

detailed: Explain contour intervals (lines close together = steep).
Show how flat cardboard layers stacked up create a slope (topography model).
Discuss cut-and-fill strategies for placing foundations.
Trace contour shapes onto cardboard sheets.
Cut out the layers carefully.
Stack and glue them to form a hill.
Identify a flat spot suitable for building a house model.

trioCompliance.justification: Earth Science and Geography concepts applied to Engineering.

activities.title: 14. Solar Studies: Orientation and Light
activities.description: Analyzing the path of the sun to optimize building orientation for energy efficiency using simulation.
learningObjectives: Understand the sun's path (East to West, angle changes by season).
Orient a building to maximize/minimize heat gain.
Design overhangs for shading.

detailed: Explain passive solar design principles (Heat gain in winter, shade in summer).
Demonstrate high summer sun vs. low winter sun angles using flashlight.
Discuss window placement (South facing for gain).
Place the model house on the desk.
Use the flashlight to simulate summer (overhead) and winter (low angle) sun.
Observe where the light enters the building.
Add an awning (cardstock) to block summer sun but admit winter sun.

trioCompliance.justification: Environmental Science and Physics.

activities.title: 15. HVAC & Airflow: Ventilation Simulation
activities.description: Using simple smoke or streamers to visualize airflow and understand natural ventilation dynamics.
learningObjectives: Understand the Stack Effect (hot air rises).
Design cross-ventilation strategies.
Visualize invisible fluid dynamics.

detailed: Define HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning).
Demonstrate the 'Stack Effect' using a heat source (lamp) and smoke in a box.
Explain how windows on opposite walls create airflow (Cross ventilation).
Draw a diagram predicting airflow in a house with windows open at top and bottom.
Observe the teacher demonstration of smoke movement.
Refine the diagram based on observation of fluid dynamics.

trioCompliance.justification: Physics (Thermodynamics) instruction.

activities.title: 16. Sustainable Design: The Passive House
activities.description: Students integrate previous lessons to design a home that requires minimal energy inputs.
learningObjectives: Synthesize concepts of orientation, insulation, and materials.
Draw a section view showing sustainable features.
Explain the benefits of Green Building.

detailed: Introduce LEED certification and Passive House standards.
Discuss insulation (R-value) and thermal bridging.
Show examples of green roofs, rainwater harvesting, and solar power.
Sketch a cross-section of a house.
Label at least 5 sustainable features (e.g., Solar panels, thick insulation, south-facing windows, rain barrels).
Write a brief pitch for why this house is eco-friendly.

trioCompliance.justification: Environmental Science and Engineering integration.

activities.title: 17. Project Management: Cost Estimation
activities.description: The math of constructioncalculating the cost of materials for a simple room renovation.
learningObjectives: Calculate area of walls and floor.
Determine paint and flooring quantities needed.
Create a budget spreadsheet.

detailed: Provide a simple floor plan (e.g., 10x12 room).
Provide unit prices (e.g., Paint covers 400sqft for $30; Flooring is $2/sqft).
Explain contingency funds (adding extra for mistakes).
Calculate total wall area (excluding windows/doors) and floor area.
Using the price list, calculate the total cost to renovate the room.
Add 10% for waste/overage to the final budget.

trioCompliance.justification: Applied math and financial literacy (budgeting).

activities.title: 18. Landscape Architecture: Zoning and Flow
activities.description: Designing the outdoor space to complement the building and serve human needs through botany and planning.
learningObjectives: Distinguish between hardscape and softscape.
Design circulation paths.
Create a landscape plan.

detailed: Define Landscape Architecture (it's not just gardening).
Discuss the importance of native plants (xeriscaping) in Texas climates.
Explain how people move through outdoor spaces (paths of desire).
Draw a site plan for a community park.
Indicate walking paths, seating areas, and trees.
Use symbols to represent different plant types (Trees vs Shrubs).

trioCompliance.justification: Biology (Botany) and Design integration.

activities.title: 19. Urban Planning: The Neighborhood Layout
activities.description: Scaling up from a single building to a community, focusing on zoning, infrastructure, and civic responsibility.
learningObjectives: Understand zoning (Residential vs Commercial vs Industrial).
Plan a walkable community.
Place infrastructure (roads, power).

detailed: Explain why factories aren't usually next to houses (Zoning codes).
Discuss the concept of the '15-minute city' (everything needed is within walking distance).
Divide class into groups acting as the 'City Council'.
Collaborate to draw a city map on large paper.
Designate zones for housing, schools, and shops.
Draw the road network connecting them.

trioCompliance.justification: Civic engagement and systems engineering.

activities.title: 20. Capstone: The Dream Community Center
activities.description: Final presentation where students apply all learned skills to design a community center.
learningObjectives: Synthesize structural, aesthetic, and functional design.
Present a design proposal verbally.
Critique peer work constructively.

detailed: Set the prompt: Design a community center for your neighborhood.
Establish rubric: Must include floor plan, elevation, and one sustainable feature.
Facilitate the 'Design Jury' (presentations).
Pin up drawings/models from previous lessons (or create new ones) on the board.
Present the design to the class (3 minutes).
Explain the structural system and sustainable features used.

trioCompliance.justification: Culminating academic project demonstrating mastery of STEM concepts.
